lay the body of Elizabeth, my love, my wife; so lately
living, so dear, so worthy. She had been moved from
the posture in which I had first beheld her, and
now as she lay her head upon her arm, and a
handkerchief thrown across her face and neck I
might have supposed her asleep. I rushed towards
her, and embraced her with adrour but the
dealthy languour of the limbs told me that what
I now held in my arms had ceased to be the Eliza
beth whom I had loved and cherished; the [Vol. III-G 121][murder
rous mark of the fiend's grasp was on her neck,
and the breath had ceased to issue from her lips.
